Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Analyze the Standard Hire-to-Retire Process: What is the typical flow? 1. Post Job Advertisement. 2. Screen Candidates. 3. Conduct Interviews. 4. Make Hiring Decision. 5. Onboard Employee. 6. Add to Payroll. 7. Close Case. Key Dependencies: You cant interview before screening. You cant decide before interviewing. You cant onboard before deciding to hire. You cant add to payroll before onboarding. Screening and Interviewing are usually sequential. Payroll is mandatory for a hired employee.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Analyze POWL Model 1: Structure: StrictPartialOrder. Nodes: Post Screen Decide Interview Onboard Payroll Close. Edges: Post -> Screen Screen -> Decide Screen -> Interview Decide -> Onboard Onboard -> Payroll Payroll -> Close. Visualizing the Flow: Post starts. Screen happens. After Screen: Screen -> Decide AND Screen -> Interview. Decide and Interview can happen in parallel after Screen OR Decide without Interview. No edge between Interview and Decide. Implication: Make Hiring Decision before or parallel to Conduct Interviews. Interview is a dead end. Anomalies: 1. Decision before during Interview. 2. Interview Orphan. 3. Missing Interview -> Decide.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Analyze POWL Model 2: Structure: StrictPartialOrder containing Operators LOOP XOR. Nodes: Post Screen Interview Decide loop_onboarding xor_payroll Close. Operators: loop_onboarding LOOP(Onboard skip). xor_payroll XOR(Payroll skip). Edges: Post -> Screen Post -> Interview Interview -> Decide Decide -> loop_onboarding loop_onboarding -> xor_payroll xor_payroll -> Close. Anomalies: 1. Parallel Screening Interviewing Post -> Screen and Post -> Interview. 2. Optional Payroll XOR(Payroll skip). 3. Looping Onboarding LOOP(Onboard skip). 4. Missing Screen -> Interview dependency.

Name: Abductive Reasoning - IND
Text: Compare and Evaluate: Model 1 Issues: Logic flow broken Decide before Interview Interview useless. Model 2 Issues: Optionality Payroll repetition Onboarding loose Screen Interview order. Which is Better? Model 1 preserves mandatory steps no skips no loops. Model 2 gets sequence right but introduces optionality repetition. Critical: Model 1 Interview disconnected from Decide. Model 2 Interview -> Decide exists but Payroll optional.

Name: Backtracking - PE
Text: Weighing the anomalies: Model 1 sequence error. Model 2 compliance error. Re-evaluating Model 1: Decide and Interview concurrent. Re-evaluating Model 2: Interview -> Decide correct but Payroll optional. Normative: Screen -> Interview -> Decide -> Onboard -> Payroll. Model 1 violations: Interview not before Decide. Model 2 violations: Screen not before Interview Payroll not mandatory Onboard repeated. Model 1 1 major violation Model 2 3 violations.

Name: Counterfactual Reasoning - PE
Text: In Model 1 process can reach Close without Interview finishing? In PO all nodes must complete. In Model 2 XOR Payroll means Payroll does not have to happen. Missing Payroll worse than Interview Decide overlapping.

Name: Heuristic Reasoning - PE
Text: Model 1 enforces Payroll mandatory. Model 2 optional. Missing step higher severity than wrong order. Model 1 structurally safer mandatory steps.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Self-Correction on Model 1: Interview mandatory in Strict Partial Order all must execute. Self-Correction on Model 2: XOR allows skipping. Comparison: Missing step Model 2 vs Wrong order Model 1. Missing higher severity.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: Conclusion: Model 1 preferable enforces completion all critical steps even if sequencing flawed. Model 2 allows skipping compliance steps.
